details.overview: If you're on a low income, you can get savings interest tax-free or at a lower rate - but if you're on a high income you must pay extra tax
details.body:
Interest on your savings and investments is automatically taxed at 20%. But if you have a low level of taxable income, you can get it tax-free or claim back tax you’ve paid.

When your interest is tax-free

You can get your savings and investment interest tax-free if your taxable income in the 2012 to 2013 tax year is less than:

  • £8,105 if you’re under 65
  • £10,500 if you’re aged 65 to 74
  • £10,660 if you’re 75 or older

If you get Blind Person’s Allowance or Married Couple’s Allowance, these figures will be higher. Check using HM Revenue & Customs’ (HMRC) calculator.

Ask your bank or building society to pay your savings and investment interest tax-free by filling in form R85.

Download ‘Form R85 - Apply for tax-free interest on your savings’ (PDF, 190KB)

When you can reclaim tax

You can reclaim up to half the tax that’s already been taken from the interest on your savings and investments if your taxable income in the 2012 to 2013 tax year is more than the amounts above but less than:

  • £10,815 if you’re under 65
  • £13,210 if you’re aged 65 to 74
  • £13,370 if you’re 75 or older

When you reclaim, your non-savings income is counted before your savings interest. So if most of your income isn’t from savings interest, you’ll only get half the tax back on part of your savings interest.

Send ‘Form R40’ to HMRC to get a repayment.

Download ‘Form R40’ (PDF, 102KB)

When you must pay additional tax

You must pay extra tax on your savings and investment interest if you pay Income Tax at the higher or additional rate.

If you fill in a Self Assessment tax return each year, you’ll pay the extra tax either:

  • as part of your Self Assessment bill
  • through your employer or pension provider - HMRC will tell them how much to deduct

If you’re not paying the extra tax due on the interest, you must let HMRC know.
